content:
I am curious how these two classes are meant to be differentiated.

At first look, Repr looked more informative and can actually return String via reprStr function. But I also realized that (1) there is no subclass relation between Repr and ToString, which looks intentional, and (2) deriving keyword supports Repr, while not ToString.

I am defining lots of structures and cannot define ToString for each of them and deriving ToString doesn't work. Thus, I have added

instance [Repr α] : ToString α where toString := reprStr

and am using deriving Repr instead. I am worried if I am doing something that is discouraged.

My understanding: ToString is for a user-friendly string representation, and Repr is for a representation that is (hopefully!) parseable as Lean source code.

I don't think there's any harm in a low-priority Repr->ToString instance like that in your own project, but I'd be sure to make it be low-priority.

@Kyle Miller Thanks! That is relieving :)
Just out of curiosity - what kind of potential issue do you foresee when regarding priority?
If it's not low priority, then the Repr instance could take priority over a pre-existing ToString instance.
Ah, I see. That would be problematic. Thanks!
Youngju Song has marked this topic as resolved.
